\begin{document}

\title{Financial Tech in the Aid Industry: Bitcoin and Crowdfunding}


\author{Bastiaan Quast}
\maketitle
\begin{abstract}
The internet impacts virtually everything around us, the first half
of this decade has finally seen that impact extend to the financial
sector. This paper discusses two recent innovations in financial technology
- Bitcoin and crowdfunding - in relation to the aid industry.
\end{abstract}

\section{What is Bitcoin?}
\begin{itemize}
\item Bitcoin (capital B): the network / protocol 
\item a bitcoin (miniscule b): a coin
\end{itemize}

\section{How does Bitcoin work?}
\begin{itemize}
\item public ledger
\item anonymous addresses
\item alternative cryptocurrencies
\end{itemize}

\section{Economics of Bitcoin}
\begin{itemize}
\item value from nothing, like gold
\item deflationary
\item not Legal tender, why not relevant
\item tax avoidance
\item illegal transactions
\end{itemize}

\section{Uses of Bitcoin}
\begin{itemize}
\item remittances
\item mobile payments
\item store of value (when compared to unstable currencies, e.g. ARS)
\item online 'tipping'
\item crowdfunding 
\end{itemize}

\section{Bitcoin and the Aid Industry}
\begin{itemize}
\item source of funding

\begin{itemize}
\item tipping
\item crowdfunding (e.g KeePod)
\end{itemize}
\item tying remittances to mobile payments
\item trace transactions and destinations in public ledger
\item independance of local currency, exchanges etc.\end{itemize}

\end{document}
